docs.title: Secure Cloudflare Tunnel Access to Code-Server (pacard-sawmill)
docs.text: This document outlines the full configuration used to expose code-server on pacard-sawmill securely over the internet using Cloudflare Tunnel and Cloudflare Zero Trust. This ensures maximum security, no LAN exposure, and MFA-protected access from anywhere.

docs.title: Overview-2
docs.text:
This setup provides:

  • Secure remote access to code-server
  • Zero Trust identity protection (email + MFA)
  • No VPN required
  • No ports opened on your home network
  • code-server bound only to localhost for safety
  • Cloudflare Tunnel handles all public traffic

Traffic flow:

You → Cloudflare Zero Trust → Cloudflare Tunnel → pacard-sawmill → code-server

LAN access is intentionally disabled.

docs.title: 1. Install cloudflared on pacard-sawmill
docs.text:
curl -fsSL https://github.com/cloudflare/cloudflared/releases/latest/download/cloudflared-linux-amd64.deb -o cloudflared.deb
sudo dpkg -i cloudflared.deb

Authenticate the instance:

cloudflared tunnel login

Choose the domain osirispc.com.

docs.title: 2. Create the Tunnel
docs.text:
cloudflared tunnel create pacard

This creates credentials:

/home/osirisortiz/.cloudflared/<UUID>.json

docs.title: 3. Configure the Tunnel
docs.text:
Create and edit the config:

sudo mkdir -p /etc/cloudflared
sudo nano /etc/cloudflared/config.yml

Paste:

tunnel: pacard
credentials-file: /home/osirisortiz/.cloudflared/<UUID>.json

ingress:
  - hostname: code.osirispc.com
    service: http://127.0.0.1:8080
  - service: http_status:404

Replace <UUID> accordingly.

docs.title: 4. Create DNS Route
docs.text:
cloudflared tunnel route dns pacard code.osirispc.com

This creates the necessary CNAME record.

docs.title: 5. Install and Start the Tunnel Service
docs.text:
sudo cloudflared service install
sudo systemctl enable cloudflared
sudo systemctl start cloudflared

Verify:

systemctl status cloudflared

Should show: Active (running).

docs.title: 6. Secure with Cloudflare Zero Trust
docs.text:
Navigate to:

Cloudflare Dashboard → Zero Trust → Access → Applications → Add Application

Select Self-hosted.

Configure:

  • Domain: code.osirispc.com
  • Name: Code Server

Access policy:

Action: Allow
Selector: Emails
Value: osirisortizpc@gmail.com

This requires identity login + MFA before accessing code-server.

docs.title: 7. Configure code-server to Bind Locally Only
docs.text:
File:

~/.config/code-server/config.yaml

Recommended:

auth: none
bind-addr: 127.0.0.1:8080
cert: false

Restart code-server:

pkill -f code-server
code-server

docs.title: External access (WORKS):
docs.text: https://code.osirispc.com

docs.title: Local machine access (WORKS):
docs.text: http://127.0.0.1:8080

docs.title: LAN access (BLOCKED intentionally):
docs.text:
http://192.168.199.177:8080

This is the expected Zero Trust behavior.

docs.title: Optional: Enable LAN Access Later
docs.text:
Change:

bind-addr: 0.0.0.0:8080

Restart code-server.

LAN devices will now reach the service.

docs.title: Result
docs.text:
You now have:

  • A secure, MFA-protected Cloudflare Tunnel
  • A globally accessible development environment
  • Zero exposure on your LAN
  • A professional Zero Trust setup
  • Fully isolated code-server endpoint

This configuration is ideal for a hardened, flexible, secure homelab.

docs.title: 🌲 1) How to Start the Dev Environment (Every Time)
docs.text: Whenever you want to edit your Homelab Docs, do this:

docs.title: ✅ Step 1 — Go to your project
docs.text: cd ~/projects/homelab-docs

docs.title: ✅ Step 2 — Activate your virtual environment
docs.text:
source .venv/bin/activate

You should see:

(.venv)

docs.title: ✅ Step 3 — Start MkDocs with live reload (the working mode)
docs.text:
export MKDOCS_WATCH=1
mkdocs serve -a 0.0.0.0:8002

This gives you:

  • Dynamic updates
  • Polling mode (solved your code-server issue)
  • Instant reload
  • Smooth editing

docs.title: 🧭 Your site is now live at:
docs.text:
http://192.168.199.177:8002/

When you’re done working:

docs.title: ❌ Stop the server
docs.text:
Just press:

CTRL + C

Done.

docs.title: 🌲 **2) Homelab Docs – MkDocs Dev Environment Setup
docs.text: This page explains how to start the development server for the Homelab Docs project. Following these steps ensures live reload, correct file watching, and a clean workflow.

docs.title: 1. Navigate to the Project Directory
docs.text: cd ~/projects/homelab-docs

docs.title: 2. **Activate the Python Virtual Environment
docs.text:
source .venv/bin/activate

Once activated, your prompt will show:

(.venv)

docs.title: 3. Enable Polling Mode (Required for code-server)
docs.text:
export MKDOCS_WATCH=1

Polling mode ensures MkDocs correctly detects file changes when using code-server.

docs.title: 4. Start the MkDocs Development Server
docs.text:
mkdocs serve -a 0.0.0.0:8002

The site will become available at:

http://192.168.199.177:8002/

docs.title: 5. Stopping the Server
docs.text:
Press:

CTRL + C

docs.title: Watch Setting in mkdocs.yml
docs.text:
This project requires a manual watch directive so MkDocs always tracks the correct folder:

watch:
  - docs

docs.title: Why We Use Polling Mode
docs.text: Because code-server writes files in a way that breaks standard file watchers, MKDOCS_WATCH=1 forces MkDocs to use a reliable, polling-based watcher that never misses changes.

docs.title: That’s it.
docs.text: You now have a fully working development workflow for Homelab Docs.

docs.title: 📘 Pi-hole + Unbound Deployment (Host Networking Mode)
docs.text: A Lodge Infrastructure Case File

docs.title: 📝 Overview
docs.text:
This document describes the complete setup of Pi-hole with Unbound running on an Ubuntu 24.04 virtual machine using Docker. This configuration gives you:

  • Network-wide ad blocking
  • Full recursive DNS (no 3rd-party DNS)
  • Local hostname resolution
  • High privacy
  • Fast DNS caching
  • Simple failover options

Pi-hole operates in host networking mode for maximum reliability, while Unbound runs in a standard Docker bridge network (exposing port 5335).

docs.title: 🖥️ VM Requirements
docs.text:
• Ubuntu Server 24.04 LTS
  • Static IP: 192.168.199.53
  • 1 CPU / 1–2GB RAM minimum
  • Docker installed
  • UFW disabled or configured to allow DNS (port 53)

docs.title: 🧰 Install Docker & Docker Compose
docs.text:
sudo apt update
sudo apt install docker.io docker-compose -y
sudo systemctl enable --now docker

docs.title: 📦 Directory Structure
docs.text:
Create the directory:

mkdir -p /opt/pihole
cd /opt/pihole

docs.title: 🧾 Docker Compose File
docs.text:
Create:

sudo nano /opt/pihole/docker-compose.yml

Paste:

version: "3.3"

services:
  pihole:
    container_name: pihole
    image: pihole/pihole:latest
    network_mode: host
    environment:
      TZ: "America/New_York"
      WEBPASSWORD: "admin"
      DNSMASQ_LISTENING: all
    volumes:
      - ./etc-pihole:/etc/pihole
      - ./etc-dnsmasq.d:/etc/dnsmasq.d
    restart: unless-stopped

  unbound:
    container_name: unbound
    image: mvance/unbound:latest
    ports:
      - "5335:53/tcp"
      - "5335:53/udp"
    restart: unless-stopped

docs.title: ▶️ Deployment
docs.text:
Run:

cd /opt/pihole
sudo docker-compose down
sudo docker-compose up -d --force-recreate

Verify the containers:

docker ps

You should see:

  • Pi-hole running and healthy
  • Unbound running on port 5335

docs.title: 🧪 Testing DNS
docs.text:
Test recursion and forwarding:

dig @192.168.199.53 google.com
dig @192.168.199.53 cloudflare.com
dig @192.168.199.53 nasa.gov

Expected output:

  • status: NOERROR
  • ANSWER SECTION
  • Times varying from 1ms (cached) to 100+ms (recursive)

docs.title: ⚙️ Pi-hole Configuration
docs.text:
Go to:

http://192.168.199.53/admin

docs.title: Upstream DNS
docs.text:
Disable all upstream DNS providers.

Add only:

127.0.0.1#5335

docs.title: Advanced DNS settings
docs.text:
Enable:

  • ✔ Listen on all interfaces
  • ✔ Never forward non-FQDNs
  • ✔ Never forward reverse lookups for private ranges

docs.title: 🏠 Optional: Conditional Forwarding
docs.text:
To resolve local device names:

Settings → DNS → Conditional Forwarding

  • Local network: 192.168.199.0/24
  • Router IP: 192.168.199.1
  • Local domain name: lan

docs.title: 📡 Router Configuration
docs.text:
Point LAN DNS to:

192.168.199.53

All clients will now use Pi-hole → Unbound → Root DNS servers.

docs.title: ❌ connection refused
docs.text:
Cause: Pi-hole not running in host networking OR port 53 in use.

Fix:

  • Ensure network_mode: host is present
  • Restart Pi-hole

docs.title: ❌ docker-proxy appears in ss output
docs.text:
Cause: Pi-hole using ports: mapping instead of host networking.

Fix:

  • Remove ALL ports: from Pi-hole config
  • Redeploy containers

docs.title: ❌ Unbound not responding
docs.text:
Check port:

dig @127.0.0.1 -p 5335 google.com

If no response:

  • Unbound container not ready
  • Port blocked
  • Container crashed

docs.title: ❌ Pi-hole not resolving LAN hostnames
docs.text:
Enable Conditional Forwarding OR add host records in:

/etc/pihole/custom.list

docs.title: 🧭 Summary
docs.text:
You now have:

  • Full DNS privacy
  • No 3rd-party upstream DNS
  • Root-level recursion
  • Fast caching
  • Pi-hole running natively at host network speed

A clean, secure, resilient Lodge DNS system.

If you'd like an advanced version of this doc with:

🔧 Hardening (DNSSEC, QNAME minimization, root anchors) 📊 Grafana dashboards 🔥 High availability (2nd Pi-hole) 📦 GitHub-ready SOP version 🔺 Twin Peaks–themed version

Just say the word.

🧩 Overview
docs.text: Pi-hole 1 (192.168.199.53) is now operating as the primary DNS server for the network. The secondary DNS has been left as Cloudflare (1.1.1.1) temporarily for redundancy during observation.

docs.title: 🌐 Router DHCP Configuration (TP-Link)
docs.text: DHCP Server: Enabled IP Address Pool: 192.168.199.99 – 192.168.199.201 Address Lease Time: 120 minutes Default Gateway: 192.168.199.1 Primary DNS: 192.168.199.53 (Pi-hole 1) Secondary DNS: 1.1.1.1 (Cloudflare, temporary fallback)

docs.title: 🧠 Pi-hole 1 Details
docs.text:
• Status: Running normally
  • IP Address: 192.168.199.53
  • Role: Primary DNS server for LAN
  • Container health: Healthy (FTL process active)
  • DNS test results: Successful resolution via nslookup google.com 192.168.199.53

docs.title: 🕵️ Monitoring Instructions (48-hour observation)
docs.text:
1. UI → Query Log: Confirm steady traffic and minimal “retried” queries.
  2. UI → Tools → Network: Verify active client list is populating.
  3. From any LAN host:

bash nslookup cloudflare.com 192.168.199.53

  • Should return valid IPv4/IPv6 results quickly.
  • If browsing stalls:

bash pihole -t

  • Use this to tail real-time logs and confirm query flow.

docs.title: 🪶 Next Steps (after stability confirmed)
docs.text:
Once Pi-hole 1 proves stable:

  • Deploy new Unbound server on a clean VM (not .139).
  • Integrate Pi-hole 1 with that Unbound for recursive resolution.
  • Remove Cloudflare fallback (1.1.1.1) to enforce full DNS filtering.

docs.title: ⚙️ Next Change Procedure: Switching to Recursive Unbound
docs.text:
1. Deploy Unbound Container:

bash docker run -d --name unbound \ -p 5335:5335/tcp \ -p 5335:5335/udp \ -v /opt/unbound/etc:/etc/unbound \ --restart unless-stopped \ mvance/unbound:latest

  1. Update Pi-hole Upstream DNS in UI: Go to Settings → DNS → Upstream DNS Servers and set:

Custom 1 (IPv4): 127.0.0.1#5335

  1. Disable Cloudflare Fallback: Remove 1.1.1.1 from your router’s DHCP config.

  2. Verify with dig/nslookup:

bash dig google.com @127.0.0.1 -p 5335

If that resolves, Unbound is active.

  1. Reboot Clients or Flush DNS:

bash ipconfig /flushdns # Windows sudo systemd-resolve --flush-caches # Linux

  1. Monitor Logs:

bash docker logs -f unbound pihole -t

Once Unbound has stable recursion, log the new baseline as Phase 2: Recursive DNS.

docs.text:

docs.title: pacard-sawmill
docs.text: Role: Development server / code-server host OS: Ubuntu 24.04 LTS (VM) Primary IP: 192.168.199.177 Status: Active

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: pacard-sawmill serves as the main development environment for internal and external projects. It runs code-server, Docker, and several MkDocs documentation sites.

docs.title: Key Services
docs.text:
• code-server (code.osirispc.com via Cloudflare Tunnel)
  • Portainer Agent (port 9001)
  • Homelab Docs (homelab-docs auto-commit + watcher)
  • Docker-based development containers

docs.title: Maintenance Notes
docs.text:
• Automatic updates via unattended-upgrades
  • Auto-commit logs rotate every 50 lines
  • Watched in real-time by homelab-autocommit.service
  • Backups planned for sync to theowlcave NAS

docs.title: theblacklodge
docs.text: Role: Secondary Proxmox Node (Backup / mirror media server) OS: Debian 12 (bookworm) Primary IP: 192.168.199.101 Status: Active (standby replication node)

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Black Lodge acts as the failover counterpart to The White Lodge. It mirrors media libraries, configurations, and snapshots via ZFS and rsync. When The White Lodge goes dark, The Black Lodge assumes its identity temporarily.

docs.title: Key Services
docs.text:
• Jellyfin (standby configuration)
  • RARR stack (backup, disabled by default)
  • Rsync mirror target for /mnt/data/movies and /mnt/data/shows
  • Portainer Agent for container control

docs.title: Maintenance Notes
docs.text:
• Receives media and config sync via lodge-mirror.sh
  • Keeps ZFS snapshots aligned daily
  • Does not delete missing files (append-only sync)
  • PBS handles local and offsite backups

docs.title: Failover Plan
docs.text: During failover, The Black Lodge mounts the mirrored datasets and starts the Jellyfin container. Cloudflare DNS may be updated manually or via Keepalived floating IP for continuity.

docs.title: thewhitelodge
docs.text: Role: Primary Proxmox Node OS: Debian 12 (bookworm) Primary IP: 192.168.199.100 Status: Active

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The White Lodge hosts several vm's. The main RARR stack: Radarr, Sonarr, Jellyfin, qBittorrent, and Gluetun. It serves as the production media hub for the network and the primary sync source for The Black Lodge.

docs.title: Key Services
docs.text:
• Jellyfin (Movies, Shows, Trailers)
  • Radarr, Sonarr, Prowlarr, Jellyseerr
  • qBittorrent with VPN via Gluetun
  • ZFS dataset for /mnt/data/movies and /mnt/data/shows

docs.title: Maintenance Notes
docs.text:
• ZFS snapshots replicate to The Black Lodge
  • Synced nightly using lodge-mirror.sh
  • Backed up via Proxmox Backup Server
  • Config stored in /mnt/data/configs/

docs.title: Failover Plan
docs.text: In the event of downtime, The Black Lodge takes over via manual ZFS replication and Jellyfin restore. Rsync ensures latest metadata and libraries are mirrored.
